writing_prompt: After an off-world mishap leaves Daniel tangled in thorny vegetation, Jack offers his "help" with a mix of teasing and questionable grooming advice. What happens next?
story:
Glaring at his reflection in the mirror, Daniel Jackson winced as he gingerly prodded at the small, angry scratches scattered across his face. The bathroom's harsh fluorescent lights highlighted the mess of his appearance, reminding him of the unfortunate tumble he'd taken off-world. In the grand scheme of things, a few scratches were nothing compared to the usual dangers of gate travel, but still, he'd rather not have been the source of amusement for Jack O'Neill.

Behind him, the door creaked open, and Jack sauntered in, a lopsided grin plastered across his face. "Y’know, Daniel, if I’d known you were so eager to try flying, I would’a given you lessons."

Daniel rolled his eyes, trying to ignore the heat rising to his cheeks. "Very funny, Jack. I think I was doing just fine until the ground decided to intervene."

"Sure, sure," Jack agreed with a chuckle, leaning against the doorframe. "But you’ve gotta admit, you made quite the impression on that bush."

Turning away from the mirror, Daniel faced Jack, crossing his arms defensively. "Next time, maybe you could catch me instead of letting me dive headfirst into a thorn patch?"

Jack feigned a thoughtful expression. "I dunno, Daniel. I think you’ve got a natural talent for it. Besides, it’s not every day you get to see an archaeologist try extreme gardening."

The humor in Jack’s eyes was infectious, and despite himself, Daniel found a reluctant smile tugging at his lips. "I suppose it’s a good thing I’m not easily deterred."

"That's the spirit!" Jack pushed off the doorframe and approached, examining the scratches with an exaggerated seriousness. "Though, you might want to invest in some heavy-duty moisturizer. Or maybe consider a career change to porcupine wrestling."

"Noted," Daniel replied dryly, though the corners of his mouth twitched upwards. "But I think I’ll stick to my day job."

Jack paused, his gaze flicking to the mirror before returning to Daniel. "Seriously though, how’re you holding up? Those thorns didn’t do you any favors."

Daniel hesitated, his reflection once again capturing his attention. "I’m fine. Just… embarrassed, I guess."

Jack nodded, the teasing edge softening into something more genuine. "Hey, we all have those moments. Remember the time Carter accidentally blew up her lab? Or when Teal’c got stuck in that revolving door?"

Daniel snorted at the memories. "Those were… memorable."

"Exactly," Jack said, clapping a hand on Daniel’s shoulder. "Besides, a few scratches don’t change the fact that you’re still the smartest guy I know."

The unexpected compliment warmed Daniel more than he cared to admit. He glanced at Jack, finding reassurance in his friend’s steady gaze. "Thanks, Jack."

"Anytime." Jack gave his shoulder a gentle squeeze before stepping back. "Now, how about we get you cleaned up before Carter decides to turn this into a team bonding exercise?"

Daniel chuckled, the tension easing from his shoulders. "Sounds like a plan."

Together, they left the bathroom, Daniel feeling a little less tangled in his own self-doubt, and more grateful for the friendship that made even the most embarrassing mishaps bearable.

writing_prompt: A man insists he has a solid alibi for a murder investigation but begs the detectives not to reveal it to his wife—what secret could be worth risking suspicion?
story:
Detective Dee Laytner leaned back in his chair, arms crossed, eyes narrowed at the nervous man seated across from him in the interrogation room. The man, Richard Grant, was fidgeting with his fingers, glancing nervously towards the one-way mirror. Dee exchanged a look with his partner, Ryo MacLean, who sat beside him, and both detectives leaned in slightly, ready to listen.

“Listen,” Richard began, his voice a tad too high-pitched. “I swear, I didn’t kill anyone. I have an alibi. I just… I can’t let my wife know about it.”

Dee raised an eyebrow, intrigued. “You know how that sounds, right? If you’ve got an alibi, it could clear you. But you’re more worried about your wife finding out?”

Richard nodded vigorously. “Exactly! Look, it’s not what you think. I mean, it’s nothing illegal or… or immoral. It’s just embarrassing.”

Ryo leaned forward, his expression gentle. “Mr. Grant, we’re just trying to clear things up. If you have a solid alibi, it’s in your best interest to tell us. We’ll do our best to keep it discreet.”

Richard swallowed hard, casting another anxious glance at the mirror. “Alright, fine. But you have to promise me you won’t let this get back to her.”

“We’ll do our best,” Dee assured him, his curiosity piqued.

Richard took a deep breath. “I was at the golf course.”

“Golfing?” Dee asked, incredulous. “That’s your big secret?”

Richard shook his head fervently. “I wasn’t golfing. I was… well, I was taking golf lessons.”

Ryo blinked. “I’m not following. Why is taking golf lessons something you can’t let your wife know?”

Richard sighed, a deep, weary sound. “My wife, Linda, she’s… she’s obsessed with golf. She’s been golfing since she could walk, practically. And me? I’m terrible at it. But she doesn’t know that. She thinks I’m just not interested. I’ve been pretending to hate it for years to avoid embarrassing myself.”

Dee bit back a laugh, glancing at Ryo, who was struggling to keep a straight face. “So, you were secretly taking lessons?”

“Every Tuesday,” Richard admitted, looking mortified. “It’s the only time I can get away without raising suspicion. I didn’t want her to know because… well, if she found out I was sneaking around to learn golf, she’d insist on teaching me herself. And I’d rather have my eyeballs removed with a spoon than go through that humiliation.”

Ryo nodded, finally understanding. “So, you were at the golf course when the murder happened?”

“Exactly,” Richard confirmed, relief evident in his voice. “I can prove it too. The instructor, George, he’ll vouch for me. Just… please, don’t let Linda find out.”

Dee chuckled. “Alright, we’ll talk to George. And if your story checks out, we’ll keep it under wraps. But you owe us one.”

Richard exhaled, visibly relaxing. “Thank you. You have no idea how much this means to me.”

As the detectives left the interrogation room, Dee couldn’t help but laugh. “Golf lessons, of all things. What’s next, secret knitting clubs?”

Ryo grinned. “Hey, everyone’s got their secrets. At least this one’s harmless. Besides, it’s kind of sweet in a way.”

“Sweet?” Dee scoffed, but he was still smiling. “I guess so. Just goes to show, people will go to great lengths to keep their pride intact.”

The two detectives made their way to the golf course, where George the instructor confirmed Richard’s story. With a promise to keep the secret safe, they returned to the precinct, ready to close the case on Richard Grant.

“Another day, another mystery solved,” Dee quipped, leaning back in his chair once more. “Think we can convince the captain to let us out early for some real golf?”

Ryo chuckled, shaking his head. “You know, if you actually spent time practicing, you might not embarrass yourself next time we go.”

“Yeah, yeah,” Dee replied, smirking. “But where’s the fun in that?”

The End

writing_prompt: After a long day of chasing toddlers, cleaning up chaos, and wrangling mischievous pets, Ianto finally collapses into bed—only for Jack to come home late from work with stories of his own. How do two exhausted partners find comfort in the chaos of their shared life?
story:
Ianto lay sprawled on the bed, staring at the ceiling, listening to the quiet hum of the night outside their window. The room was a sanctuary of calm, a stark contrast to the whirlwind that had been his day. With a sigh, he let the tension ebb away, muscles sinking into the mattress, eyes drifting shut.

Then came the soft click of the door, a familiar creak as it swung open, and Ianto felt the mattress dip beside him. Jack was home, finally.

“Long day?” Jack murmured, a hint of amusement in his voice as he settled beside Ianto, his presence a warm, comforting weight.

“You could say that,” Ianto replied, turning his head to meet Jack’s gaze. “If you consider a naked toddler sprinting through the flat like an Olympic champion and a cat with a vendetta against the curtains as ordinary.”

Jack chuckled, the sound rich and soothing. “Sounds like the kids had a productive day.”

Ianto snorted. “Productive isn’t quite the word I’d use, cariad. More like…chaotic. I swear, Owen’s managed to turn every bit of furniture into a jungle gym, and don’t get me started on the baby powder incident. It was like a blizzard had hit the living room.”

“Wish I could’ve seen that,” Jack said, a fond smile tugging at his lips.

“Be grateful you missed it. Took me ages to clean up.” Ianto shifted closer, letting Jack’s warmth seep into him, a balm against the day’s madness. “How was your day? Anything exciting in the world of Torchwood?”

Jack sighed, a sound heavy with exhaustion. “Oh, the usual. Aliens trying to invade Cardiff, Weevils causing a ruckus in the sewers. You know, just another Tuesday.”

“Sounds positively mundane,” Ianto teased, his voice laced with affection.

“Almost as mundane as your day,” Jack quipped, his hand finding Ianto’s, fingers interlocking in a gesture so familiar and grounding.

They lay in comfortable silence, the weight of the day slowly dissipating, replaced by the simple comfort of being together. Here, in this quiet room, with the chaos of their lives momentarily held at bay, they found solace.

“I’m glad we have this,” Ianto said softly, his voice a mere whisper in the dark.

“Me too,” Jack replied, pressing a gentle kiss to Ianto’s forehead. “No matter how crazy it gets out there, it’s always good to come home to you.”

Ianto smiled, a small, contented curve of his lips. “Even if the kids are determined to turn our lives into a sitcom?”

“Especially then,” Jack said, his tone warm and full of love. “Wouldn’t have it any other way.”

And in that moment, amidst the chaos and exhaustion, they found peace—a shared understanding that whatever life threw at them, they’d face it together, hand in hand, heart to heart.

“Twpsyn,” Ianto murmured, affection lacing the word as he finally let sleep pull him under, Jack’s laughter the last thing he heard before dreams claimed him.

writing_prompt: After fainting at a crime scene and waking up in the ER with a stitched forehead, you realize the real challenge isn’t the injury—it’s surviving the relentless teasing from your partner, Dee, who seems to find your misfortune endlessly entertaining.
story:
Ryo was feeling embarrassed, but that was nothing new. He was also well aware he’d probably get teased relentlessly by his colleagues, especially Dee, who never missed an opportunity to poke fun at him. As he lay there in the sterile confines of the ER, Ryo couldn't help but replay the morning's events in his mind, cringing at each misstep that had led to his current predicament.

It had been a scorcher of a day, the kind of oppressive heat that made the air shimmer and breathing feel like a chore. They'd been called to a crime scene in the middle of a concrete jungle, the sun reflecting off the surrounding buildings, turning the area into an oven. Ryo had been sweating buckets, the heat sapping his energy and making him feel lightheaded. He'd ignored the warning signs—his own foolishness, he thought ruefully—choosing instead to focus on the job at hand. They'd been in the midst of interviewing witnesses, piecing together fragments of a narrative when the world had tilted alarmingly, colors bleeding into one another.

The next thing he remembered was waking up here, the sharp scent of antiseptic in the air, his head pounding with a dull, insistent throb. A nurse had informed him of the cut on his forehead, courtesy of the unforgiving asphalt, and the stitches he'd received while he was out cold. But the injury, though painful, was the least of his worries.

Taking another slow sip of water, Ryo leaned back against the pillows, closing his eyes against the bright lights. He could practically hear Dee's voice in his head already, dripping with feigned concern and teasing amusement. "Fainting at a crime scene, Ryo? Really outdoing yourself this time." The thought made him groan inwardly, his cheeks flushing with a mixture of embarrassment and irritation. Dee would have a field day with this one.

The heat had been relentless, the kind that wrapped around you like a suffocating blanket, and coupled with the dehydration Ryo hadn't even realized he was experiencing, it had been a disaster waiting to happen. He cursed his own stubbornness, his refusal to acknowledge his limits. It wasn't as though he hadn't been warned—Dee had been nagging him all morning to drink more water, but Ryo had brushed him off, too focused on the task at hand. Now, he had to face the consequences.

Ryo opened his eyes, staring up at the ceiling as he considered his next steps. The teasing, though inevitable, was something he could endure. It was the disappointment in himself that stung the most. He prided himself on being level-headed, on not letting emotions or circumstances cloud his judgment. Yet here he was, a victim of his own stubborn pride.

The only thing to do now was to face the music. Ryo resolved to take better care of himself, starting with acknowledging his limits. He would apologize to Dee for not listening, for brushing off his concern, and maybe, just maybe, he'd find a way to turn the teasing to his advantage. After all, Dee's humor, while sometimes exasperating, was rooted in affection. And if Ryo could survive the teasing, he could survive anything.

In the end, perhaps the real lesson was one of humility, of accepting that he wasn't invincible, that he needed to rely on those around him. And with that thought, Ryo found a sense of peace. He'd face Dee's teasing with grace, let it roll off his back like water off a duck, and maybe even join in the laughter. Because in the grand scheme of things, a little embarrassment was a small price to pay for the reminder that he wasn't alone.

The End

writing_prompt: On a planet with low gravity, your team struggles to stay grounded—literally—while navigating the strange terrain. But the real challenge begins when you discover you're not the only ones bouncing around.
story:
The Stargate whooshed shut behind them, leaving SG-1 standing on the surface of P2X-775. The landscape resembled a lush Earth forest, with trees swaying gently in a breeze, their leaves glinting under the bright, twin suns. The air was crisp and rich with oxygen, invigorating.

“Whoa!” O’Neill exclaimed as his first step sent him bounding several feet forward. “Talk about a spring in your step.”

Carter, taking a cautious hop, laughed. “It’s definitely a low-gravity environment, sir. I’d estimate about a third of Earth’s gravity.”

“Stop bouncing around like a damn kangaroo and get back here!” O’Neill called to Daniel, who was gleefully testing the limits of the alien physics.

Daniel grinned sheepishly, floating back in a series of graceful arcs. “Sorry, Jack. It’s just—this is amazing! The sense of freedom—”

“Yeah, yeah. Let’s just try not to float away, alright?” O’Neill adjusted his vest, trying to appear more authoritative despite his own unplanned leaps.

Teal’c, ever composed, took a deliberate step, flexing his knees to absorb the motion and minimize rebound. “This terrain could prove advantageous in combat, but also treacherous.”

Carter nodded, stabilizing herself by gripping a nearby tree trunk. “Agreed. We need to adjust our movements to maintain control.”

“Like this?” O’Neill attempted a slower, more calculated step, only to find himself awkwardly airborne. Carter reached out, steadying him mid-flight. “Thanks, Carter.”

“No problem, sir. It’s all about center of mass and—”

“Ya think?” O’Neill smirked, trying to regain his footing with dignity.

The team continued navigating the forest, their movements a mix of stumbling and graceful soaring. The novelty of the environment was both exhilarating and mildly frustrating. Every step had to be measured, every leap anticipated.

“So, Carter, why aren’t we seeing more wildlife?” O’Neill asked as they moved through the towering vegetation.

“Could be that the local fauna is adapted to the gravity in ways we haven’t noticed yet,” she speculated, eyes scanning the surroundings.

“Or maybe they’re just shy,” Daniel suggested, his attention caught by some peculiar markings on a tree.

The tranquility of their exploration was shattered by a sudden flurry of motion overhead. A group of small, fluffy creatures bounded through the treetops, their bodies propelled by the same low gravity. They chattered excitedly, seemingly amused by the Earthlings’ awkwardness.

“Well, I’ll be damned,” O’Neill muttered, watching the creatures with a mix of awe and amusement. “Looks like we’re not the only ones bouncing around.”

The creatures, resembling a cross between squirrels and puffballs, paused to observe the team, their bright eyes gleaming with curiosity.

“They’re adorable,” Carter remarked, unable to suppress a smile.

“One would assume they have adapted to this environment over many generations,” Teal’c observed, his stoic gaze following the energetic creatures.

“They seem friendly enough,” Daniel noted, reaching into his pack for his camera. “I’d love to study their behavior.”

“Just don’t let them hitch a ride back with us,” O’Neill warned, though there was a twinkle in his eye.

SG-1 continued onward, the creatures now their playful companions. Each step, each jump, was a reminder of the planet’s unique charm, and the team’s camaraderie shone through their laughter and banter.

As they navigated the strange terrain, the low-gravity world became a playground, a place where even seasoned explorers could find joy in the simple act of bouncing around.
